CS242 - Programming Studio is a studio course in programming.  This course is intended to give students an opportunity to write a lot of straightforward code so they get plenty of practice.  Assignments are open-ended.  Students present their code each week to their discussion section and comment on the code of others.

CS492 - Senior Design is a 2-semester capstone course.  Students meet with an outside client and solve their problem over the course of 2 semesters.  I am re-writing the syllabus to reflect the wishes of industrial partners and to require more accountability.  I am also scaling the course to accommodate many more students and projects. I co-direct this center with Dr. Jinjun Xiong of IBM. This research center has acquired more than $20M in funding from IBM, DARPA, NSF, and SRC. The center consists of 14 faculty members, 3 postdocs, more than 30 graduate students, and more than 15 undergraduate researchers. Education: The University of Texas at Austin

Experience: My research has focused on the development of a driver modeling framework that estimates the empirical reachable set will be presented, which is an alternative look at a classic control theoretic safety metric.  This method allows for us to predict driving behavior over long time horizons with very high accuracy.  This modeling framework has been applied to intervention schemes for semi-autonomous vehicles and to nuanced interactions between humans and autonomy in cooperative maneuvers.
Research conducted on human-in-the-loop systems with the Informatics and Decision Support Group, applying Active Perception techniques to surveillance applications.

Research is partially funded by the Ira A. Fulton School of Engineering under the FURI program.  The sponsoring lab is in the Center for Biosensors and Bioelectronics at the Biodesign Institute.  Projects included research and development of particle and chemical sensors to monitor personal exposure to common toxicants.  Duties included designing and assembling circuits and hardware, conducting experiments, aiding graduate students, and background research. All projects related to the NAE Grand Challenge: Biological and Human Systems.

Veriflow is the first networking company to use formal verification to eliminate change-induced network outages and vulnerabilities. The company was created by a team of computer science professors and Ph.D. students at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, and is backed by New Enterprise Associates (NEA), Menlo Ventures, the National Science Foundation and the U.S. Department of Defense. The company is headquartered in San Jose, California. To learn more, visit veriflow.net and follow us on Twitter @veriflowsystems.
